etymologies: late Middle English (denoting testing or investigation): from Old French probacion, from Latin probatio(n-), from probare ‘to test, prove’ (see prove). The legal use dates from the late 19th century

definitions: the release of an offender from detention, subject to a period of good behavior under supervision

examples.text: I went to court and was put on probation

shortDefinitions: release of offender from detention, subject to period of good behaviour under supervision

definitions: the process or period of testing or observing the character or abilities of a person in a certain role, for example, a new employee

examples.text: for an initial period of probation your manager will closely monitor your progress

shortDefinitions: process of testing or observing character or abilities of person who is new to role or job
